A nearly 0 value of p value indicates that the null hypothesis is rejected nullifying the non-existent relationship between the NPP and the explanatory variables. The LULC is not included in the MLR as the data type does not fit the requirement. The result analyses all other parameters by ignoring the impact of LULC. The “estimate” value of the MLR denotes to what extent the NPP changes for every unit change in the variable value. The maximum value of the estimate was in 2011 for NDVI where every unit change in NDVI resulted in 1.87 units of increase in NPP. At the same time, in 2011 EVI had a negative impact on NPP with a value of \(-0.83\). The intercept value represents the contribution of NPP under the assumption that all other variables have no influence forms the baseline for NPP. Intercept turned out to be mostly positive, significant with an average value of 1.19 s only to NDVI with an average of 1.25 (Tables S3 and S4). Through the years, PPT, NDVI, and LAI have been consistently positive and significant indicating that an increase in these variables will result in a higher NPP. The variables with significant negative consequences are EVI and LST. TEMP and FPAR have varied effects showing both positive and negative (Fig. 7).Fig. 7(a) The estimates provide insight into the magnitude and direction of the relation between the independent variable and NPP. (b) The t-value determines the significance of the statistics.Full size imageDiscussionRainfall has proven to be a crucial factor in deciding the NPP levels30 although a delayed effect is seen in the study (Table S8). Precipitation also indirectly decides the magnitude of NDVI, EVI, LAI, and FPAR through edaphic factors. The consequent delayed impact on vegetation health due to reduced precipitation is because it takes time to influence soil moisture followed by vegetation indices. Optimal temperature is necessary for balanced NPP as either extremes in temperature will cause stress, reducing NPP. LST can directly influence the plant temperature along with the soil moisture. An increased plant respiration and evapotranspiration leading to duress in vegetation is seen in higher LST which is more apparent during periods of reduced PPT. NDVI and EVI which are fed by precipitation are measures of density and health of vegetation and rise with NPP. The drought study in India31,32, observed that there was a monsoon drought during the year 2002, which was also reflected in the NPP in the area in the subsequent year. This could have happened because the NPP is strongly related to the soil moisture and the soil moisture decreases significantly, affecting soil moisture recovery, and plant water availability.A noticeable dip in NPP in 2019 (Fig. 4) indicates a general declining trend in the productivity of forest areas, despite an overall increase in forests. The LAI for forests shows a slight increase from 2001 to 2022 but the increase is not substantial enough to offset the decline in NPP, suggesting that other factors (like tree density or health) might be influencing productivity. Another reason could be that due to the expansion of forest areas into less fertile regions or younger forests that are less productive. During the 2016–2019 period, when NPP dropped by 0.24 kg C m\(^{-2}\) year\(^{-1}\), a decline in vegetation health and productivity is observed through reduced NDVI and EVI (Fig. 9). The decline of NPP in Savannas had a change rate of \(-4.75\) to \(-4.99\)%, indicating a possibility of ecological shifts or substantial reduction in trees outside forests or sparse trees33 during that period (Fig. S2). Moderate impact of LST was observed in the croplands, influencing productivity to some extent while indices such as FPAR and LAI remained stable indicating consistent photosynthetic activity and vegetation cover. This period corresponds to a high negative change rate, suggesting severe ecological stress or conversion to other land uses. Since the NDVI and EVI show significant declines, confirming reduced vegetation health and productivity and also the higher temperatures during the critical period exacerbated stress. The significant reduction in barren land and a slight increase in water bodies suggest efforts in land reclamation or natural changes.The region witnessed a decreasing trend in nearly \(50\%\) of the area while \(29\%\) saw an increasing trend. The significantly increasing and decreasing pattern occupied about \(10\%\) and \(12\%\) respectively. The increasing trend is spread out mainly in the northern end of the boundary from Vansda all the way down to the Chandoli Forest which covers the states of Gujarat and Maharashtra. Towards the eastern half, the significance of the trend is more pronounced as the slope is favorable for agricultural practices in comparison to the northwestern part. The scattered distribution of a significantly increasing trend is also seen near Periyar region among others all of which are found along the periphery and characterised by low elevation and gentle slope. It is noticed that most of the consequential rises in NPP fall under the Tropical-Savanna and Arid-Steppe-Hot climatic zones. The savannas throughout the area, show a combination of increasing and decreasing trends. Forest prominently shows a decreasing and significantly decreasing trend. The highly downward trend of NPP is observed in the lower elevation of Tropical-monsoon and Tropical-Savanna zones in Karnataka and Kerala (Fig. 8).Fig. 8The NPP trend from 2001 to 2023 in the major LULC classes.Full size imageThe magnitude of influence of each factor is largely indirect as none of the factor shows more than \(18\%\) impact on NPP. It is clear that the anthropogenic factor indicated by LULC is the main variable in increasing NPP. Although it is common knowledge that the increase in human activity results in decreased forest cover and hence should bring down the NPP, this is not true in this case. We observe a rise in NPP prominently witnessed along the edges of the boundary where there is an increase in cropland which is a vital contributor. A high value of annual average NPP is found in the built-up as croplands surround them. The interaction detector aids in comprehending how each pair of variables impacts NPP detailed in Table 6. The type of interaction helps to understand whether the combined effects of variables are synergistic, additive, or antagonistic. All interactions with PPT result in a nonlinear enhancement, indicating a strong synergistic effect where the combination of PPT with other variables (like TEMP, LULC, etc.) produces a higher impact than the sum of their individual impacts. Most interactions involving TEMP result in a bi-variable enhancement, showing that the combined impact is greater than the individual impacts but less than their sum. The interaction with other variables such as vegetation indices (EVI, NDVI) and land use (LULC) suggests that moderate temperature changes, when combined with optimal land use and vegetation conditions, can significantly boost NPP. However, the interaction with slope results in a uni-variable weaken, indicating a weaker combined effect. LULC interactions show a bi-variable enhancement for all combinations, suggesting the interaction amplifies the effects but not to the extent of their sum. This highlights the significant role of land use practices and vegetation cover in modulating ecological productivity. Proper management and conservation of land resources in the Western Ghats can enhance the positive effects of climatic variables on NPP. EVI, NDVI, LST, LAI, and FPAR interactions generally exhibit bi-variable enhancement except when combined with slope, where a nonlinear enhance is observed. When combined with slope, the interactions show nonlinear enhancement, indicating that in areas with varied topography, the presence of healthy vegetation can lead to significantly higher NPP.Despite the linear relationship linking EVI and NDVI, there is a striking difference in their impact on NPP which can be explained by the ability of EVI to highlight the thick vegetation cover. The MLR model revealed that NDVI had the highest estimate followed by the intercept value. The coefficient for precipitation is highly significant and positive across most years which directly implies an increase in NPP. However, in some years, such as 2006 and 2018, the coefficient is negative, suggesting that other factors might be interacting with precipitation to reduce NPP in those years. LST coefficients are consistently negative and highly significant, indicating that higher land surface temperatures generally reduce NPP.Fig. 9The graphical representation of the result features the impact of different parameters in creating altering scenarios of NPP in the region. The NPP during 2003–2005 showed a decrease for a prolonged duration owing to increased LST, along with a decline in the indicated variables. In the years 2011, and 2022 a similar condition of higher NPP was recorded. This was preceded by high rainfall and reduced LST and temperature. The NPP witnessed the worst conditions in 2019 with very high temperatures and LST scenarios coupled with moderate rainfall and NDVI.Full size imageConclusionThe key indicators of NPP were PPT, NDVI, and LAI affecting positively, while EVI, and LST had generally a negative impact. The temperature displayed a varying effect depending on the year. The influence of predictors like temperature and precipitation on NPP is not uniform across years. This variability can be attributed to different environmental conditions, such as soil moisture, nutrient availability, and interaction with other climate factors. The consistently negative EVI coefficients suggest a complex dynamic where densely vegetated areas might not always translate to higher productivity. The power of the anthropogenic factor proved to be the highest followed by vegetation parameters driven by climatic conditions and barely any by the topographic indicator. The results from the interaction detector indicate that the interplay of precipitation, temperature, LULC, and vegetation indices significantly amplify NPP, highlighting the critical role of these variables in driving ecological productivity. The reduction in cropland area reflects ongoing changes in land use patterns within the Western Ghats, necessitating sustainable land management practices to maintain and potentially enhance cropland productivity amidst environmental and anthropogenic pressures. Although the average NPP of the Western Ghats saw a large drop in 2019, the ecological resilience helped the NPP to bounce back to the normal level by 2020. The NPP is decreasing in the forests even though the forests are increasing which may be attributed to the introduction of newer and younger forests. Apart from the chosen parameters, NPP is also influenced by soil moisture, \(CO_2\) level, humidity, dew point temperature, soil type and quality, wind, ecosystem type, and more. Future studies including all these parameters will provide more insights into the dynamics of NPP. In conclusion, the Western Ghats’ productivity is shaped by a combination of climatic variables, land use changes, and vegetation health. Effective management and conservation strategies are essential to mitigate the negative impacts and enhance the positive effects of these factors on NPP. The findings underscore the need for a holistic approach to preserve the biodiversity hotspot and sustain its ecological productivity. From a policy perspective, the results indicate a need to build a strong local governance through community based conservation efforts, and effective landscape level zoning. To sustain the forest productivity, as strict and locally driven conservation practices should be implemented to monitor the changing land use pattern. Integrating sustainable practices with stronger policy enforcement will be key to preserving the resilience of this critical biodiversity hotspot. The research underscores the urgency of integrating climate resilience into conservation strategies for the Western Ghats, renowned for its biodiversity and ecological importance, in response to significant climate threats.MethodsStudy areaThe Western Ghats boasts of being a landscape with rich ecological diversity sustaining all the forest classifications from grasslands to tropical wet evergreen forests, flowering plants having about 4000 different species, and ample fauna34. The forest types in the Western Ghats characterized as non-equatorial tropical evergreen forests have four major phenological attributes. The majority of the area is occupied by moist deciduous forests succeeded by semi-evergreen forests which have a greater level of vegetation diversity, evergreen forests with maximum level of endemism, and lastly, the dry deciduous forests prevalent on the leeward side of the mountain34. The Western Ghats sees a shift in climate with proximity to the equator as the latitude changes from 8\(^\circ\) 07’ 58” N to 21\(^\circ\) 15’ 58” N and the longitude from 72\(^\circ\) 53’ 31” E to 78\(^\circ\) 03’ 45” E (Fig. 10). The area expands from the coastline to a height of 2619 m above the mean sea level witnessing a range of topographic and climatic conditions. Stretching to a length of approximately 1500 Km, the study area stretches for 107,770 sq km from the southern tip of India, the Kanyakumari in Kerala to south of Gujarat including the Maharashtra, Goa, Karnataka, and Tamilnadu states35. The annual average precipitation is about 190 cm whereas the mean maximum and minimum precipitation is about 590 cm and 40 cm respectively. The minimum and maximum temperature in the region average 15 \(^\circ\)C and 30 \(^\circ\)C respectively while the annual average is around 26 \(^\circ\)C. This mountain range surfaced as a significant uplift along a rift shoulder during the Deccan Trap volcanic activity at the boundary between the Late Cretaceous and Paleocene epochs36. Owing to the tectonic action during the formation period, the northern and southern Western Ghats display contrasting geology with the Deccan traps consisting of basalt in the north and Charnockites, Granulites, Khondalites, etc in the south34.Fig. 10The research site accessorized with the climate classification and elevation.Full size imageDataTerrestrial productivity in the Western Ghats is quantified using NPP as the primary indicator. To understand the influence of various factors on NPP, the climate indicators (precipitation, air temperature, and land surface temperature), topography (slope), vegetation indices (NDVI, EVI, LAI, and FPAR), and anthropogenic factors, specifically Land Use and Land Cover (LULC) changes were examined (Table S2).NPPThe NPP refers to the fuel, fiber, and food source for the sustenance of human life. The spatial variation in the terrestrial biological productivity is crucial for measuring the global change pointing to the CO\(_2\) levels. This variation spans from approximately 30 gCm\(^{-2}\) for desert landscapes to as high as 1000 gCm\(^{-2}\) for the lush evergreen tropical rain forests. The product’s design is aimed to precisely measure the growth or activity of the terrestrial vegetation on a regular interval. Three major components form the basis for estimating terrestrial NPP from satellites. They include the direct relation of NPP to the absorbed solar energy, the theoretical link between satellite-derived vegetation characteristics and the absorbed solar energy, and the dissection of the reason for fluctuation in the efficiency of final conversion37.The MOD17A3H MODIS/Terra Net Primary Production Yearly L4 Global 500 m product was used in the study. The crop productivity shows a linear relation with the quantity of the absorbed solar energy and the absorbed Photosynthetically Active Radiation (APAR) according to the radiation use efficiency logic proposed by Monteith38 which forms the basis for the MOD17 algorithm. The actual productivity is estimated by translating the APAR using the conversion efficiency parameter, \(\epsilon\), which is determined by the climatic condition and vegetation type. MOD17 also calculates the respiration parameters. The improved version of the MOD17 algorithm (Collection 6.1) replaces the LAI product (\(LAI_{max}\)) dependent growth respiration (\(R_g\)) with \(R_g = 0.25*NPP\) for the calculation of MODIS NPP. \(R_g\) is the cost of energy used for organic compound construction. This upgrade reduces the mishap where the \(R_g\) value would be greater than NPP at times when the MODIS \(LAI_{max}\) would be set at 6.8 for the forest pixels39.$$\begin{aligned} N=G-R_m-R_g=G-R_m-0.25*N \end{aligned}$$
                    (1)
                where, N stands for Net Primary Productivity, G for Gross Primary Productivity, and \(R_m\) and \(R_g\) stand for annual plant maintenance respiration and growth respiration respectively.$$\begin{aligned} \begin{aligned} N&=0.8*(G-R_m) \quad when \quad G-R_m\ge 0, \quad and\\ N&=0 \quad \quad \quad \quad \quad \quad \quad \,\,\,\, when \quad G-R_m<0 \end{aligned} \end{aligned}$$
                    (2)
                PrecipitationMulti-Source Weighted-Ensemble Precipitation, version 2 (MSWEP V2)40 gridded precipitation product provides 3 hourly global data since 1979 with \(0.1^\circ\) spatial resolution. The data is formulated by merging the precipitation estimates from multiple sources such as the gauge data, satellite, and reanalysis products. To enhance the accuracy in the frequency of precipitation, bias correction methods, and correction for regional variations are introduced. The spatial pattern of magnitude, frequency, and mean precipitation demonstrated by MSWEP V2 is highly realistic. Precipitation datasets usually underestimate the magnitude in regions with mountains which is overcome by MSWEP V2.TemperatureThe MSWX is the Multi-Source Weather near-surface global meteorological product for temperature with 3-h temporal resolution and \(0.1^\circ\) spatial resolution41. The data is bias-corrected and with the help of reference climatological data, it is also down-scaled. The temperature information is obtained through a process based on cumulative distribution function (CDF)-matching. This process entails resampling the model data to 0.1\(^\circ\) using nearest neighbor interpolation, converting the model data to indices via a static matrix of evenly spaced data points, choosing the relevant correction factors from another static matrix of correction factors based on these indices, and finally, applying these correction factors to the model data through multiplication.LULCThis data plays a crucial role in understanding the changing features of the region. The Annual International Geosphere-Biosphere Programme (IGBP) classification from the MODIS Land Cover data (MCD12Q1.061) which has a 500 m spatial resolution and 17 classes is adopted for the study. The dataset is created and prepared by applying a decision tree algorithm based on the combination of MODIS NDVI, surface reflectance, albedo band parameters, and land surface temperature42. For the purpose of the study, as the 2023 LULC was not available, 2022 LULC was used for 2023 as well. The IGBP classification has 17 classes which were grouped into 9 classes based on their characteristics for better interpretation and understanding (Table S2).NDVIThe MODIS NDVI product (MOD13Q1.061) is available with a spatial resolution of 500 m at 16-day intervals. The usage of NDVI in the biogeochemical and circulation models is crucial at all scales from local to global43.$$\begin{aligned} NDVI = \frac{\rho _{NIR}-\rho _{red}}{\rho _{NIR}+\rho _{red}} \end{aligned}$$
                    (3)
                where variables \(\rho _{NIR}\) and \(\rho _{RED}\) represent the bidirectional reflectance factors for the corresponding MODIS bands at the surface level.EVIEVI is a vegetation monitoring tool with higher sensitivity than NDVI. The MODIS EVI product (MOD13Q1.061) uses the sensor’s near-infrared (\(\rho _{NIR}\)), red (\(\rho _{red}\)), and blue (\(\rho _{blue}\)) bands. It is beneficial in studying the vegetation characteristics such as phenology, stress, and productivity in areas of dense biomass as it reduces the influence of atmosphere and surpasses the saturation problem present in NDVI. The calculation of EVI involves the soil-adjustment factor, coefficients of variation adjustments, and canopy background adjustments44.Land surface temperature (LST)The MODIS LST product (MOD11A2.061) which is a 8 day 1 Km resolution data is derived using the generalized split-window algorithm. Based on the land cover types, and atmospheric column water vapour, lower boundary air surface temperature, the 31 and 32 bands are estimated for the emissivities. Manageable sub-ranges of temperatures are calculated for efficient retrieval45.LAI and FPARThe LAI and FPAR products from MODIS (MOD15A2H.061) are developed from surface reflectances using the vegetation canopy radiative transfer algorithm46. This was put into implementation before the launch of MODIS on the TERRA platform.Digital elevation model (DEM)A globally continuous DEM with 30 m spatial resolution depends on applying radar interferometry algorithms to the Shuttle Radar Topography Mission (SRTM) data, which is then processed into a locally spherical coordinate system47.Experimental frameworkTrend analysisThe Mann Kendall (MK) test48,49 is applied to analyze the trend of the time series NPP data from 2001 to 2023. The nonparametric test checks for an increasing or a decreasing trend, along with the significance and monotonicity of the statistics. The trend may or may not be linear. The MK test holds an advantage over the regression analysis which requires the residual data to be normally distributed. The trend present is quantified by testing if the time series falls within the confidence interval which is given by the null hypothesis and the significance level50.$$\begin{aligned} S=\sum _{k=1}^{j-1} \sum _{l=k+1}^{j} sgn(a_l-a_k) \end{aligned}$$
                    (4)
                where the length of the NPP data is represented as j, while \(a_l\) and \(a_k\) are the sequential data values.$$\begin{aligned} sgn(a_l-a_k) = {\left\{ \begin{array}{ll} 1, if(a_l-a_k) >0\\ 0, if(a_l-a_k) =0\\ -1, if(a_l-a_k)<0 \end{array}\right. } \end{aligned}$$
                    (5)
                The mean is given as E(S) and variance as Var(S), with the random distribution of the variable, the normal distribution is approximated when \(j\ge 8\).$$\begin{aligned} & E(S)=0 \end{aligned}$$
                    (6)
                $$\begin{aligned} & \quad Var(S) = \frac{j(j-1)(2j+5)-\sum _{k=1}^{m}d_k(d_k-1)(2d_k+5)}{18} \end{aligned}$$
                    (7)
                where for the extent k, \(d_k\) is the number of ties and m is the number of tie groups. \(Z_S\) denotes the test statistics.$$\begin{aligned} Z_S = {\left\{ \begin{array}{ll} \frac{S-1}{\sqrt{Var(S)}}, if S>0\\ 0, if S=0\\ \frac{S+1}{\sqrt{Var(S)}}, if S<0\\ \end{array}\right. } \end{aligned}$$
                    (8)
                The result of the test reveals an increasing and decreasing trend with a positive and negative \(Z_S\) respectively. A test uses a confidence level of \(95\%\) with an \(\alpha\) value of 0.05.GDMSpatial heterogeneity is a fundamental characteristic of geographic phenomena. The models are statistically designed to detect spatially stratified heterogeneity and uncover the underlying driving forces27. The analysis of the spatial variability is covered by the GDM using the four geographical detectors. It is used to assess the influence of climatic and meteorological parameters on the productivity of the forest through geographical strata. The areas of risk are identified by the risk detector, and the factor responsible for it is recognized by the factor detector. The relative prominence of the parameters is revealed by the ecological factor and the interaction detector decides if a parameter can independently contribute to the fluctuation in the change in NPP51.Factor detectorIt is used to determine how much each natural factor contributes to the spatial distribution of NPP. The goal is to assess how each natural factor individually impacts the spatial distribution of NPP. The methodology involves several steps: first, spatial superposition and analysis of the NPP layer and natural factor layers; second, division of the natural factors into different spatial categories or classes; and finally, calculation of the mean differences of these natural factors. The significance test is then used to determine the relative importance of each natural factor. The F-test determines if there is a significant difference in the variances.$$\begin{aligned} F=\frac{\sigma ^2_{A,\, p}}{\sigma ^2_{A,\ r}} \end{aligned}$$
                    (9)
                where, \(\sigma ^2_{A,\, p}\) is the dispersion variance, and \(\sigma ^2_{A,\ r}\) is the stratified population dispersion variance. The geographical strata are defined as r and p is the sample units in each strata, while A represents the variable.$$\begin{aligned} B_{WG}=q=1-\frac{\sigma ^2_{A,\, r}}{\sigma ^2_{A,\, p}} \end{aligned}$$
                    (10)
                \(B_{WG}\) is the power of determinant of z to the NPP. As the q value (\(0< q < 1\)) increases, so does the influence of the influence of the factor.Interaction detectorThe detector explains the factor \(A'\) and \(A{''}\) on the NPP. The procedure involved the following steps: first, we computed the q values for \(A'\) and \(A{''}\), denoted as \(q(A')\) and \(q(A{''})\), respectively. The interaction between the two factors is calculated as \((q(A' \cap \, A{''}))\) to understand the type of interaction. In this study, we used the interactive detector to measure the coupling effect of topography and climate factors on NPP51,52. The criteria to segregate the values into interaction types is detailed in Table 7.Table 7 The conditions to realize the impact of pairwise combined effect on NPP is described. The effects of individual variables are non-linearly diminished by the interaction of two variables (\(NL\cdot Wn\)). The effects of individual variables are weakened by single-variable interactions (\(UV\cdot Wn\)). The effects of individual variables are enhanced by two-variable interactions (\(BV\cdot Enh\)). The impacts of variables operate independently of each other (IN). The effects of variables are amplified in a non-linear manner (\(NL\cdot Enh\)).Full size tableRisk detectorIt is employed to determine if there was a notable difference in the mean attribute between two subregions of each factor and to identify areas where NPP had either declined or improved. t-test53. The risk for the geographical zone r is defined as \(Z_r\). The t-test is carried out with number of samples p in the r zone as \(n_{r,p}\)$$\begin{aligned} t_{\overline{Z_{r=1}}-\overline{Z_{r=2}}} = \frac{\overline{Z_{r=1}}-\overline{Z_{r=2}}}{\left[ \frac{1}{d_{r=1,\, p}}\sigma ^2_{\overline{Z_{r=1}}}+\frac{1}{d_{r=2,\, p}}\sigma ^2_{\overline{Z_{r=2}}}\right] ^{1/2}} \end{aligned}$$
                    (11)
                degree of freedom$$\begin{aligned} df=\frac{\left[ \frac{1}{d_{r=1,p}}\sigma ^2_{\overline{Z_{r=1}}}+\frac{1}{d_{r=2,\, p}}\sigma ^2_{\overline{Z_{r=2}}}\right] }{\frac{1}{d_{r=1,\, p^{-1}}} \left[ \frac{1}{d_{r=2,\, p}}\sigma ^2_{\overline{Z_{r=1}}} \right] ^2 + \frac{1}{d_{r=2,\, p^{-1}}} \left[ \frac{1}{d_{r=2,\, p}}\sigma ^2_{\overline{Z_{r=2}}} \right] ^2} \end{aligned}$$
                    (12)
                null hypothesis \(H_0: \overline{Z_{r=1}}=\overline{Z_{r=2}}\)if \(\left| t_{\overline{Z_{r=1}}-\overline{Z_{r=2}}} \right| > t_{\alpha /2}\)Ecological detectorThe model aimed to assess if the impact of any two factors on the evolution of NPP varied significantly. The analysis determined whether \(A_1\) had a greater effect on the spatial distribution of NPP compared to \(A_2\), using the F statistic for measurement. The dispersion variance for \(A_1\) and \(A_2\) are defined as \(\sigma ^2_{A_1,\, r} = \frac{1}{d_{A_1,\, p}}\sum _{r=1}^{d_{A_1,\, r}}\sum _{p=1}^{d_{r,\, p}}\left( Z_{A_1, \,p} - \overline{Z_{A_1,\, p}}\right) ^2\) and \(\sigma ^2_{A_2,\, r} = \frac{1}{d_{A_2,\, p}}\sum _{r=1}^{d_{A_2,\, r}}\sum _{p=1}^{d_{r,\, p}}\left( Z_{A_2, \,p} - \overline{Z_{A_2,\, p}}\right) ^2\) respectively. The test is defined as$$\begin{aligned} F=\frac{d_{A_1,\, p}(d_{A_1,\, p}-1)\sigma ^2_{A_1,\, r}}{d_{A_2,\, p}(d_{A_2,\, p}-1)\sigma ^2_{A_2,\, r}} \end{aligned}$$
                    (13)
                Multiple linear regression (MLR)Analyzing the impact of multiple independent variables on one dependent variable is achieved through the MLR54,55. The regression assumes that the dependent variable is directly related to a linear combination of the explanatory variables. The regression model is formulated as:$$\begin{aligned} x=\beta _0+\beta _1y_1+\cdots +\beta _ny_n+\epsilon \end{aligned}$$
                    (14)
                where x is the dependent variable, and \(y_i\) is the independent variable. When all the explanatory variables are 0, \(\beta _0\) is the constant of the dependent variable. \(\beta _i\) is the coefficient of the explanatory variable and \(\epsilon\) is the error coefficient. The t value is the representation of the test statistics of the two-sided t-test. The likelihood of the result to have occurred by chance is inversely related to the t value.The validation of the MLR model fitness assumes that there is a low or nonexistent correlation between the explanatory variables. The data set is checked to fulfill the assumptions for MLR. Independent observations are made, the variance of residuals is constant throughout the linear model, and normal distribution is observed for the residual of the model. A nearly linear relationship is seen between the explanatory variables and NPP. The residual values are estimated very close to zero and the data is nearly equally distributed on both the positive and the negative side which reiterates the assumption of the data upholding heteroscedasticity. The Pearson correlation was used to test for multicollinearity, which indicated that LAI and FPAR produced a very high positive correlation (> 0.7) and hence theoretically it was not suitable to be used. So an alternate MLR model was derived by excluding the LAI and FPAR parameters. The resulting plot did not show any significant change. Also when comparing the \(R^2\) value, the model with all the parameters showed a high value of \(R^2\) which meant that the model was a better fit for the dataset. Also, the model with all the parameters had a smaller RMSE value. In conclusion, despite the independent parameters of LAI and FPAR having a high correlation with each other, they were utilized in the MLR since removing them did not have any benefit in the model performance. From the results obtained from \(R^2\), RMSE, Adjusted \(R^2\), MAE, Average RMSE across 10 folds, AIC value, BIC value it is deduced that despite the assumption not being completely satisfied, the model with all the parameters is the best-fitted model.

Data availability
              
              All data were sourced from open-access databases, with detailed information provided in the supplementary file. The MODIS NPP data is available from https://lpdaac.usgs.gov/products/mod17a3hgfv061/. The precipitation dataset can be accessed from https://www.gloh2o.org/mswep/. The temperature is obtained through https://www.gloh2o.org/mswx/. The LULC data is available via https://lpdaac.usgs.gov/products/mcd12q1v061/. The EVI and NDVI products are made accessible through https://lpdaac.usgs.gov/products/mod13q1v061/. The LST data is procured from https://lpdaac.usgs.gov/products/mod11a2v061/. The LAI and FPAR datasets are made available at https://lpdaac.usgs.gov/products/mod15a2hv061/. The elevation product was obtained from https://lpdaac.usgs.gov/products/srtmgl1v003/.

items.description: Le Associazioni: “La Bocciatura della Corte dei Conti a difesa delle tasse dei cittadini. IL PONTE NON STA IN PIEDI DAL PUNTO DI VISTA AMBIENTA
items.body:
30 Ottobre 2025

Legambiente

30 Ottobre 2025

Comunicati stampa

ponte

Ponte sullo Stretto. Le associazioni commentano la bocciatura della Corte dei Conti

30 Ottobre 2025

Legambiente

30 Ottobre 2025

Comunicati stampa

ponte

Le Associazioni: “La Bocciatura della Corte dei Conti a difesa delle tasse dei cittadini. IL PONTE NON STA IN PIEDI DAL PUNTO DI VISTA AMBIENTALE, ECONOMICO E ANCHE PROCEDURALE”. Il primo soggetto terzo che si pronuncia sul Ponte lo boccia. Gravissimi gli attacchi alla magistratura contabile dello Stato che ha certificato tutte le anomalie di un progetto insostenibile da tutti i punti di vista”

La Corte dei Conti ha bocciato ieri la delibera CIPESS (n. 41/2025) relativa al progetto del Ponte sullo Stretto di Messina, negando il visto di legittimità all’opera da 13,5 miliardi di euro. Una decisione che conferma le gravi criticità segnalate dalle associazioni ambientaliste alla magistratura contabile e che tutela le tasse dei cittadini che il governo ha deciso di destinare ad un intervento che non sta in piedi dal punto di vista progettuale, ambientale, economico e procedurale.
Greenpeace Italia, Legambiente, Lipu e WWF Italia, avevano presentato alla Corte dei Conti due dettagliate memorie in cui evidenziavano le molteplici irregolarità del progetto: dalla violazione delle normative europee e nazionali in materia ambientale, all’insostenibilità economica dell’opera, fino alle criticità procedurali che hanno caratterizzato l’intero iter autorizzativo.
“La Corte dei Conti ha confermato ciò che sosteniamo da anni: il progetto del Ponte sullo Stretto è un’opera insostenibile sotto ogni profilo” dichiarano congiuntamente le quattro associazioni, che aggiungono: “Il primo soggetto ‘terzo’ chiamato a pronunciarsi sul Ponte non ha potuto fare altro che evidenziarne tutte le problematiche irrisolte. I magistrati contabili hanno rilevato criticità fondamentali: dalle coperture economiche incerte, all’affidabilità delle stime di traffico, dalla conformità alle normative ambientali e antisismiche, fino alla violazione delle regole europee sul superamento del 50% del costo iniziale del progetto senza nuova gara d’appalto. Tutto l’iter seguito dal Governo Meloni è stato caratterizzato da continue forzature che non sono mai state risolte, ma che si è tentato di superare con ulteriori forzature, come i continui voti di fiducia per aggirare la discussione e il confronto in Parlamento, finendo per determinare un ‘mostro’ giuridico con pesanti elementi di anticostituzionalità”.
Le associazioni ricordano che nella memoria presentata a metà settembre alla Corte avevano messo in evidenza proprio questi aspetti cruciali: “Avevamo contestato, oltre ai vizi istruttori relativi alla procedura di Valutazione di impatto ambientale (VIA) e alla Valutazione di incidenza (VInca), in violazione delle direttive comunitarie, l’utilizzo strumentale dei motivi imperativi di rilevante interesse pubblico (IROPI), con la ridicola forzatura di definire il Ponte come ‘opera militare’ per aggirare i vincoli ambientali. Avevamo sollevato dubbi sull’assegnazione dell’opera senza bando di gara internazionale, in contrasto con le norme europee sulla concorrenza”.
“Ancora più grave – proseguono le associazioni – è l’incertezza sui costi reali dell’opera, che già oggi partono da 13,5 miliardi, ma che potrebbero lievitare drammaticamente, come sempre accade per le grandi opere in Italia. La relazione costi-benefici presentata dal Governo si basa su calcoli del tutto irrealistici sull’incremento del PIL e sui flussi di traffico previsti”.
Greenpeace Italia, Legambiente, Lipu e WWF Italia sottolineano inoltre come il progetto presenti carenze progettuali ancora irrisolte. Mancano studi sismici fondamentali, non sono stati completati test di tenuta essenziali e troppe decisioni vengono rinviate al progetto esecutivo. La Corte dei Conti ha evidenziato che manca persino il parere del Consiglio Superiore dei Lavori Pubblici sul progetto definitivo e quello dell’Autorità dei Trasporti sul piano tariffario.
Tutte questioni già ampiamenti illustrate e oggetto di due ricorsi amministrativi e tre reclami alla Commissione Europea tuttora pendenti.
“Le reazioni scomposte del Governo contro la magistratura contabile rappresentano un’anomalia costituzionale senza precedenti, che apre un conflitto evidente tra l’esecutivo e chi è chiamato dalla Costituzione a controllare la sostenibilità economica degli atti. Ricordiamo che quegli atti sono finanziati con le tasse dei cittadini” dichiarano con durezza le associazioni.
Le quattro organizzazioni ambientaliste ribadiscono che il Ponte sullo Stretto rappresenta uno spreco insostenibile di risorse pubbliche che potrebbero essere impiegate per le reali esigenze – anche infrastrutturali – del Sud e dell’intero Paese.
Se il Governo manifestasse l’intenzione di forzare la mano e procedere comunque con una delibera del Consiglio dei ministri ignorando la bocciatura, le associazioni sono pronte a reagire: “Una eventuale forzatura istituzionale di questa portata rappresenterebbe una grave violazione dello Stato di diritto e minerebbe la credibilità del nostro Paese in Europa. Se ciò dovesse avvenire non esiteremo a portare la questione davanti alla Corte di Giustizia Europea per la violazione delle norme comunitarie in materia ambientale, di concorrenza e di corretta gestione delle risorse pubbliche. Un governo che procede contro i rilievi della magistratura contabile si assume una responsabilità politica e giuridica enorme che ricadrebbe anche sul Parlamento”.
